images.title: Jito-Solana Client Performance Comparison: Uptime and Block Production
images.description: The image presents a performance comparison of the Jito-Solana client, focusing on stake-weighted average uptime and block production for validators running the Jito client versus others. The data is sourced from Jito's MEV-boosted client adoption and its impact on Solana validators' performance. Two line graphs are displayed. The first graph compares the stake-weighted average uptime for validators running the Jito client (True) against those that are not (False), across epochs ranging from approximately 375 to 415. The uptime is measured on the y-axis, ranging from 95% to 100%. The Jito client consistently shows a higher uptime, generally around 99% to 100%, while the validators not running the Jito client fluctuate between approximately 98% and 99%. The second graph compares the stake-weighted average block production rate for validators running the Jito client (True) against those that are not (False), across the same epoch range. The block production rate is measured on the y-axis, ranging from 87.5% to 97.5%. The Jito client generally shows a higher block production rate, fluctuating between approximately 95% and 97.5%, while the validators not running the Jito client show more volatility, dipping below 90% at times.

images.title: StakeNet Architecture Diagram
images.description: The image illustrates the StakeNet architecture, a network of keepers and on-chain programs designed to transparently operate intelligent stake pools. The diagram shows a series of 'Keepers' (Keeper 1, Keeper 2, Keeper 3, up to Keeper N) at the top, which feed into a 'crank' mechanism. This crank then interacts with a system contained within a dashed yellow box, representing the StakeNet environment. Inside this environment, 'Validator History' feeds into 'Steward,' which in turn influences 'Delegation' and 'Scoring.' Another 'crank' mechanism connects the 'Steward' to the 'Stake Pool.' The image emphasizes that StakeNet involves a network of keepers, on-chain validator metadata, custom scoring and delegation logic, governance-adjustable parameters, and ensures no staker funds are at risk.

content.title: Jito TipRouter Operator Flow
content.description: This infographic illustrates the Jito TipRouter operator flow, detailing how Jito's TipRouter NCN redistributes MEV tips to vault operators, stakers, and the DAO efficiently. The flow begins with Jito Tips ($2.4 bn) going to the TipRouter NCN, which manages the TIP distribution. The TipRouter NCN receives security from JitoSOL Vault (Stakers, node operators) and JTO Vault (Stakers, node operators). The JitoSOL Vault receives 15 bps ($3.65 mm) from the TipRouter NCN. The JTO Vault also receives 15 bps ($3.65 mm) from the TipRouter NCN. 97% of the funds from the TipRouter NCN go to Solana Validators + Stakers ($2.36 bn), and 2.7% go to Jito Network Treasury ($66 mm). The source of the information is Jito Forum.

content.title: Jito: Dominating Solana MEV
content.summary: Jito dominates Solana MEV, offering liquid staking with MEV rewards. Jito-Solana client reduces spam, boosts validator revenue. StakeNet ensures decentralization. Jito's TVL surged 40x to $500M. JitoSOL offers high APY and MEV profits. StakeNet addresses LST centralization. Key point: Jito's MEV strategy shapes Solana's DeFi future.

bullets: Solana is rebounding strongly from the FTX crisis, showing a surge in on-chain activity, market sentiment, and enterprise integrations.
Jito's emergence as a leading liquidity staking platform on Solana, offering MEV rewards, has been instrumental in its growth, especially amidst challenging market conditions.
Jito-Solana client mitigates problems in the Solana network by reducing spam from MEV bots and increasing revenue for validators through auctions.
The Jito MEV-client creates a pseudo-mempool, conducting auctions every 200 milliseconds, allowing searchers to view incoming transactions and construct bundles for atomic execution.
Jito StakeNet addresses centralization, transparency, and sustainability issues in current LST designs by transitioning all staking logic on-chain.
StakeNet comprises a Validator History Program, storing detailed validator data, and a Steward Program, calculating scores and stake delegation for each validator.

images.title: Jito TVL and Market Share Growth on Solana
images.description: The image contains two charts related to Jito, focusing on its Total Value Locked (TVL) and market share within the Solana ecosystem. The left chart, titled 'Jito Liquid Staking TVL ($),' displays the growth of Jito's TVL over time, starting from approximately $0M on January 1, 2023, and surging to nearly $600M by December 7, 2023. The right chart, titled 'Jito-Solana Client Market Share (%),' illustrates Jito's increasing market share, beginning at around 0.00% in November 2022 and climbing to over 40.00% by December 1, 2023. Both charts indicate substantial growth and dominance of Jito within the Solana DeFi landscape. The source of the data is attributed to Defillama and p2p.org.

content.title: Monad Mainnet: Top dApps to Watch
content.summary: Four Pillars highlights dApps to watch following the Monad mainnet launch. Monad's EVM-compatible L1 network offers scalability, enabling dApps that couldn't exist on other EVM networks. The article reviews staking, DEX, lending, meme coin, gaming, AI, NFT, and RWA projects in the Monad ecosystem. Monad's ecosystem is growing.

bullets: Monad is a high-performance, EVM-compatible Layer 1 network.
Key features include MonadBFT (optimized BFT consensus), RaptorCast (efficient block transmission), and parallel execution.
MonadDb is built on a Merkle Patricia Trie, allowing direct access to trie nodes.
The Monad Ecosystem Directory lists 293 dApps.
Categories include staking, spot DEX, perp DEX, aggregator, lending, novel DeFi, prediction market, trading terminal/bot, meme coin launchpad, gaming, AI, NFT, and RWA.
Examples include aPriori, FastLane Labs, Kuru, Clober, Crystal, Capricorn, Drake, Celeris, Narwhal Finance, and Perpl.
Fortytwo is a decentralized AI network that runs small language models simultaneously.
Multisynq aims to build a new internet protocol for real-time synchronization.
Likwid combines AMM and lending in one system, enabling users to provide liquidity, borrow assets, or open long/short positions.

images.title: Builder Workflow in MEV-Boost
images.description: This infographic illustrates the Builder Workflow in MEV-Boost. The process begins with a builder submitting a block to a relay. The relay then simulates and validates the block, and if valid, sends a 'block is valid' message back to the builder. The builder then receives a signed header from the proposer. The relay publishes the block to the EL client and CL client. The CL client then publishes the block to P2P. The process concludes with the relay sending a 'block published' message back to the builder. The diagram shows the interactions between the builder, relay, EL client, CL client, and P2P.

content.title: Jito Introduction Page
content.description: The image is a screenshot of the Jito documentation website, specifically the "Introduction to Jito" page. The page provides an overview of Jito, a liquid staking service on the Solana blockchain. The content explains that Jito distributes MEV (maximum extractable value) rewards to holders. Users stake Solana tokens in exchange for JitoSOL, a liquid stake pool token. The JitoSOL token provides liquidity while earning staking and MEV rewards. The text highlights two unique aspects of Jito's liquid staking token: it provides additional rewards from MEV transactions and exclusively stakes with validators that improve network performance. The page also mentions that JitoSOL automatically accrues value from staking and MEV rewards, allowing users to earn yield while maintaining capital efficiency via DeFi integrations. A pop-up window is visible, requesting the user to agree to the Terms of Service and accept analytics and cookie policies before proceeding. The navigation menu on the left side of the screen shows different sections such as "Introduction to Jito", "Liquid Staking Basics", "Maximum Extractable Value", etc. The top navigation bar includes links to "Stake Now" and "Connect Wallet".

content.title: JIP-31 â€” BAM Early Adopter Subsidy
content.summary: Jito opened JIP-31 proposing to redirect 100% of protocol revenue to validators running BAM via an epoch-by-epoch JitoSOL merkle drop. Eligibility: validators with 50k+ SOL running BAM for 3+ epochs, correct execution/order. Mechanic: effective-stake curve (I=1.5M, g=0.5, cap=3M). Timeline: vote Jan 5, execute Jan 12, program Q1â€“Q3 2026. Unclaimed rewards roll after 10 epochs. Proposal pauses 100% buybacks temporarily; risks include inefficient DAO fund use if adoption lags.

bullets: JIP-31 proposes redirecting 100% of Jito protocol revenue to BAM validators as an Early Adopter Subsidy.
Pause: temporary halt to existing 100% buybacks executed by the CSD while subsidy runs.
Goal: accelerate validator adoption of BAM to improve Solana execution determinism and reduce harmful MEV.
Revenue distributed epoch-by-epoch in JitoSOL via a claimable merkle drop to participating validators.
Effective-stake formula: full weight up to 1.5M SOL, 0.5x weight above 1.5M, hard cap at 3M effective stake.
Unclaimed rewards roll forward into the next epoch if not claimed within 10 epochs.
Validators qualify with â‰¥50k SOL and running BAM for at least 3 epochs, maintaining correct execution feedback.
Timeline: DAO vote Jan 5, execution Jan 12; program runs Q1â€“Q3 2026, 100% revenue until early July then linearly winds down.
Risk callout: shifts revenue from value accrual to growth; if adoption lags, DAO funds could be used inefficiently.

images.title: Mechanism Curve for Effective Stake Calculation
images.description: The image presents a mechanism curve, a piecewise linear function used to calculate effective stake (eff(s)). The curve is designed to determine validators' share of a subsidy pool. The equation for eff(s) is provided: eff(s) = s when s â‰¤ I, and eff(s) = min(I + g(s - I), C) when s > I. The variables are defined as follows: s = Validator stake (SOL), I = Inflection threshold (1,500,000 SOL), g = Discount factor applied above the inflection (0.5), and C = Maximum effective stake cap (3,000,000 SOL). A graph illustrates the relationship between real stake (x-axis, in M SOL) and effective stake (y-axis, in M SOL). The graph includes a dashed gray 1:1 line, a solid blue line representing the mechanism, and red dots indicating BAM validators. The mechanism linearly increases up to the inflection point, then curves with a discount factor, and plateaus at the maximum effective stake cap.

images.title: Validator Eligibility and Distribution Mechanism
images.description: The image presents a specification outlining a validator distribution mechanism. It details that fee flows will be redirected to a foundation-managed address for distribution. An epoch-by-epoch claimable merkle drop of JitoSOL will be available to participating validators, who can claim a share of network revenue based on their active stake weight. The image then describes validator eligibility, stating that validators do not need to be active Jito stake pool members, and the subsidy program extends to validators with a threshold stake of 50k SOL running the BAM client. Validators must uphold the contract outlined in BAM docs, including executing all received transactions in exact order and providing correct execution feedback and state information. These requirements are implemented by default in the BAM validator client. Modifications that breach this contract will result in removal from the subsidy program. Validators running BAM for at least 3 epochs will gain eligibility, and eligibility will be lost if a non-BAM client is used or the contract is broken.

content.title: Kairos projection: BAM validators $2.1â€“6.3M
content.summary: Kairos Research projects BAM validators will collectively earn $2.1Mâ€“$6.3M over a 37-week subsidy program. Model assumes base weekly revenue of $140k with Â±25% and Â±50% scenarios. Tweet notes Jito will temporarily pause buybacks and redirect 100% of protocol revenue to incentivize BAM; BAM currently ~8% of stake across 120 validators.

bullets: Projected cumulative earnings between $2.1M and $6.3M across a 37-week program.
Model assumes base weekly revenue $140k with Â±25% and Â±50% scenarios (chart provided).
Jito to temporarily pause token buybacks and redirect 100% protocol revenue to BAM validators.
Current adoption ~8% of network stake across ~120 validators; incentive expected to increase adoption.

images.title: BAM Validators Cumulative Earnings from Subsidy Program
images.description:
The image is a line graph illustrating the cumulative earnings of BAM Validators from a subsidy program, assuming a base weekly revenue of $140k with scenarios of Â±25% and Â±50%. The x-axis represents 'Week' from 0 to 35. The y-axis represents 'Cumulative Earnings' in dollars, ranging from $0 to $8,000,000. There are six lines representing different scenarios:

-   50% lower (red line)
-   25% lower (orange line)
-   Base (purple line)
-   25% higher (green line)
-   50% higher (dark green line)

The graph shows that the 50% higher scenario has the highest cumulative earnings, while the 50% lower scenario has the lowest. The base scenario falls in the middle. The source is reports.firedancer.io, Kairos Research, and the data is as of December 21st, 2025.

content.title: Jito: Capturing Solana's Economics at Scale
content.summary: Kairos Research analyzes Jito's revenue streams (TipRouter, JitoSOL, Interceptor), its Block Assembly Marketplace (BAM), and potential institutional adoption via a VanEck JitoSOL ETF. Jito's tokenomics and buyback program are also discussed. Jito is positioned to outperform SOL.

bullets: TipRouter: A distributed network of node operators that captures value from priority fees on Solana.
JitoSOL: Jito's liquid staking token, providing users with staking rewards and DeFi composability.
Interceptor: A mechanism to protect the JitoSOL stake pool from arbitrage-driven exploits.
Aims to reduce extractive MEV and improve transaction execution on Solana.
Allows applications to customize transaction sequencing with transparent ordering logic.
Enables applications to monetize user activity through privileged access to backrunning arbitrage.
The VanEck JitoSOL ETF application is a clear example of institutional DeFi adoption.
JitoSOL is an integral part of any potential SOL staking ETF due to its liquidity and integrations.
Staking ETFs could add $1-2B to Jito's TVL, increasing protocol revenue.

content.title: Jito MEV Harvesting Guide
content.description: This screenshot displays the "MEV Harvesting Guide" on the Jito documentation website. The guide is for stake account holders to claim unclaimed MEV rewards. The page highlights that it is specifically for native SOL stake accounts, not JitoSOL holders, as their MEV rewards are automatically included. It directs users to the Jito Harvest page to claim accumulated MEV rewards. The page also includes a section titled "Harvest MEV" with details on "Harvest MEV Rewards from Stake", explaining that rewards are determined by stake amount and duration, and are only distributed if the validator is running the Jito client. The image also shows a pop-up window titled "Welcome to Jito" with options to agree to the Terms of Service, accept analytics and cookie policies, and buttons to decline or continue.

content.title: Jito Mechanism Curve: Real vs Effective Stake
content.description: This line chart, titled 'Mechanism Curve (Real vs Effective Stake)', visualizes the relationship between the actual amount of SOL staked (Real Stake) and the stake value used for protocol calculations (Effective Stake) in the context of Jito's BAM (Block-building and MEV) mechanism. The x-axis represents Real Stake in millions of SOL (0 to 6), and the y-axis represents Effective Stake in millions of SOL (0 to 6). A dashed grey line indicates a 1:1 ratio where real stake equals effective stake. A solid blue line represents the 'Mechanism' curve, which follows the 1:1 line until approximately 1.5M SOL, then begins to taper off, eventually plateauing at a maximum effective stake of 3M SOL once the real stake reaches 4.5M SOL. Red dots representing 'BAM validators' are plotted along this curve, showing that most current participants have a real stake between 0 and 2M SOL, placing them in the linear or early-tapering phase of the mechanism.

content.title: Validator Eligibility and Distribution Mechanism
content.description: The image presents a specification outlining a validator distribution mechanism. It details that fee flows will be redirected to a foundation-managed address for distribution. An epoch-by-epoch claimable merkle drop of JitoSOL will be available to participating validators, who can claim a share of network revenue based on their active stake weight. The image then describes validator eligibility, stating that validators do not need to be active Jito stake pool members, and the subsidy program extends to validators with a threshold stake of 50k SOL running the BAM client. Validators must uphold the contract outlined in BAM docs, including executing all received transactions in exact order and providing correct execution feedback and state information. These requirements are implemented by default in the BAM validator client. Modifications that breach this contract will result in removal from the subsidy program. Validators running BAM for at least 3 epochs will gain eligibility, and eligibility will be lost if a non-BAM client is used or the contract is broken.

### **Key Takeaways**
* **Solanaâ€™s MEV layer is real and growing.**It influences how transactions are ordered, executed, and monetized, especially at scale.
* Two markets compete for blockspace:**priority fees and bundle auctions.**Standard transactions use tips; high-value flows use Jito bundles for atomic execution.
* **Jito controls the MEV stack:**validator software, relay infrastructure, and staking. Over 95% of stake flows through this system, reshaping how value moves on Solana.
* **Not all MEV is harmful**. Bundles enable value-creating strategies like protected arbitrage and cross-protocol coordination.
* Developers must design**MEV-aware transactions.**Use bundles, simulate fees, and route sensitive flows through private relays.
Since day one, Solana has focused on delivering unmatched speed and throughput, making it a go-to choice for high-performance blockchain applications. Jito offers state-of-the-art MEV solutions that turn what was once a highly competitive, spamâ€filled race into a more efficient and transparent marketplace for extracting value. But did you know that DeFi users and dApp developers can also benefit from Jitoâ€™s MEV infrastructure to boost the reliability, efficiency, and security of their Solana transactions?
In this article, weâ€™ll explore the capabilities and benefits of the Jito MEV Client and guide you in integrating it into your Solana development workflow.
## What is Jito on Solana? Key takeaways
**Jito**is building a more efficient infrastructure to optimize MEV on**Solana**and enable faster, more predictable transaction execution. It integrates mechanisms that ensure MEV is distributed to stakers as well.
* The core piece of Jito infrastructure is a Solana validator client that is also MEV optimized. The mechanisms like bundling, block engine auctions, and relayer are part of the clientâ€™s software.
* Bundles are a feature unique to the Jito-Solana validator. Bundled transactions get guaranteed ordering and atomic execution.

# Solana MEV: An Introduction
![Ryan Chern](https://www.helius.dev/_next/image?url=%2Fapi%2Fmedia%2Ffile%2Fryanchern-author-image.jpg&w=96&q=90)
Ryan Chern
10min read
June 1, 2024
### Table of Contents
**Note:**The MEV landscape on Solana is rapidly changing. This page will be updated periodically with new developments. Read our latest[Solana MEV Report](https://www.helius.dev/blog/solana-mev-report)(Jan 2025).
## [Takeaways](#takeaways)
This post aims to provide a baseline understanding of how MEV on Solana works. In short:
* MEV on Solana is not dead.
* Not all MEV is bad.
* Profitable frontrunning is possible across DEX liquidity venues structures, not just AMMs.
* Solanaâ€™s continuous block production and lack of an in-protocol mempool changes the default behavior and social dynamics of the chain.
* Someone else may fork or try to otherwise replicate Jitoâ€™s out-of-protocol mempool to extract more MEV, but it is hard both technically and socially.
* Many validators support the decision to remove the Jito mempool, foregoing sandwiching revenue, in favor of the long-term growth and health of Solana.## [Introduction](#introduction)
In a[Proof-of-Stake network](https://www.helius.dev/blog/proof-of-history-proof-of-stake-proof-of-work-explained#whatâ€™s-proof-of-stake), when you are assigned leader of a given block, you have the authority to determine the contents of your assigned block. Maximal Extractable Value (MEV) refers to any value derived from adding, removing, or reordering the transactions within a given block.
As activity and general interest have been increasing on Solana, MEV is becoming an[increasingly discussed topic](https://x.com/aajxbt/status/1765512478316793865?s=20). On January 10, 2024, a searcher tipped a validator 890 SOL, one of the largest tips in Jitoâ€™

rawResponse.title: What Is Jito on Solana? | Complete Guide
rawResponse.text:
What Is Jito on Solana? | Complete Guide
# Jito Labs
A Complete Guide for Innovators
![Jito Labs](https://blockchain.oodles.io/wp-content/themes/blockchain-child/assets/images/sc/jito-labs.png)
## What Jito Labs Is (and Is Not)
It builds MEV and block-building infrastructure for Solana. It operates core components that improve ordering, latency, and rewards. Its stack includes the Jito-Solana validator client, the Block Engine and bundles, ShredStream, relayers, and a liquid staking program. You use these tools to route order flow, protect users, and capture lawful MEV. You also use them to observe blocks faster and coordinate complex transactions.
The platform does not sell retail â€œtrading bots.â€ It ships infrastructure, clients, and APIs that others integrate. The audience includes validators, searchers, builders, dApps, wallets, and institutional treasuries. Each group plugs into different surfaces and policies. Each group also assumes different operational risks.
## Audience Paths
1
### Validators
Run the Jito-Solana client and connect a relayer. Configure MEV tip collection and payment programs. Monitor leader schedules and slot health. Review runbooks for co-hosted or separate relayer deployments. Track MEV rewards and validator performance across epochs.
2
### Searchers and HFT firms
Build bundles for auction. Use gRPC or JSON-RPC for fast sending. Test revert protection and atomic execution. Simulate routes and fees before bidding. Align with Block Engine policy and rate limits.
3
### dApps, wallets, and bot platforms
Use private routing to avoid harmful orderflow leakage. Use low-latency send to land time-sensitive transactions. Use bundles for multi-tx atomicity. Provide users with MEV protection paths as defaults.
4
### Stakers and Treasuries
Stake SOL to the Jito stake pool and receive JitoSOL. Earn staking rewards plus MEV-driven yield. Review program docs and risk notes before onboarding capital. Track TVL, APY, and integrations in the staking hub.
##

searchParams.query: how does Jito's MEV distribution mechanism work

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The search results directly address the query. They provide detailed information on Jito's MEV infrastructure (Jito-Solana client), the distribution of tips (TipRouter), the value accrual for JitoSOL holders, and recent governance proposals (JIP-31/BAM) regarding revenue redirection. Only one result concerning Monad is off-topic.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The contents are highly informative and include detailed descriptions of infographics that break down technical flows (TipRouter operator flow) and economic models (Effective Stake Curve). The summaries are well-structured with clear headers and bullet points.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: There is a high concentration of relevant data, but some redundancy exists among the multiple posts from 'Four Pillars' which repeat historical context. Additionally, one post about Monad is irrelevant, and there is some duplication in the provided image descriptions.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: The search results provide a comprehensive answer, covering: 1) The technical mechanism of the Jito-Solana client (auctions/bundles), 2) The quantitative distribution of tips (97% to validators/stakers, etc.), 3) The difference between manual harvesting for native stakers and automatic accrual for JitoSOL, and 4) Current evolutions like the Block Assembly Marketplace (BAM).
key_strengths: Detailed breakdown of TipRouter distribution percentages (97% to validators, 15 bps to vaults, etc.)
Clear distinction between native SOL stake harvesting and JitoSOL rewards
Inclusion of recent governance developments (JIP-31) regarding the Block Assembly Marketplace
Strong visual descriptions of architecture diagrams and distribution flows
key_weaknesses: Redundancy across multiple 'Four Pillars' articles that share similar text
One irrelevant result concerning the Monad mainnet launch
Duplication of specific specification images in the search output
evaluation.overall_assessment: This search result is of very high quality. It provides both the broad conceptual overview of Jito's MEV mechanism and the granular economic data required to understand exactly how funds flow through the system. The inclusion of technical components like the TipRouter and the transition toward BAM ensures the user gets an up-to-date and complete picture of the protocol's distribution logic.

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The search results are highly relevant to the query, featuring official Jito documentation, technical deep dives, and articles specifically addressing MEV rewards, tip distribution, and the Jito-Solana validator client.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The quality is heavily impacted by the formatting of the search snippets. Out of 15 results, 8 are almost entirely comprised of navigation sidebars and menu links from the Jito Gitbook, providing zero actual explanatory text. However, a few results (2, 8, 10, and 15) provide some substantial context.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: The information density is very low because the majority of the tokens are consumed by repetitive Gitbook headers and sidebar links. The 'Tip Payment Program' and 'Tip Distribution Program' pagesâ€”which would be most relevantâ€”only display the table of contents in these snippets.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: While much of the technical detail is missing due to poor snippet extraction, the results collectively explain that validators run the Jito-Solana client, tips are collected via a Block Engine, and rewards are distributed to stakers through a liquid staking model (JitoSOL) or claimable Merkle proofs via the new TipRouter system.
key_strengths: Includes information on the modern 'TipRouter' decentralized distribution network.
Correctly identifies the roles of searchers, validators, and stakers in the reward lifecycle.
Provides a high-level overview of the Jito ecosystem (Block Engine, Bundles, Relayers).
key_weaknesses: Over-reliance on a single domain (Gitbook) which resulted in 8 redundant, nearly empty snippets.
Missing specific technical mechanics of how the distribution program calculates shares for stakers versus validators.
Several snippets are dominated by cookie consent banners or SEO metadata rather than core content.
evaluation.overall_assessment: The search results provide the right 'where' but fail significantly on the 'what' due to poor text extraction. Most official documentation links only show the navigation menu. To get a complete answer, a user would need to rely on the summary in result 15 and the data-heavy snippet in result 2 regarding TipRouter. The overall quality is salvaged by the presence of the TipRouter result, which explains the claim-based distribution and Merkle root consensus.

![Solana MEV Economics: The Role of Jito, Bundles, and Liquid Staking](https://blog.quicknode.com/content/images/size/w1200/2025/07/2x1--4-.png)
### **Key Takeaways**
* **Solanaâ€™s MEV layer is real and growing.**It influences how transactions are ordered, executed, and monetized, especially at scale.
* Two markets compete for blockspace:**priority fees and bundle auctions.**Standard transactions use tips; high-value flows use Jito bundles for atomic execution.
* **Jito controls the MEV stack:**validator software, relay infrastructure, and staking. Over 95% of stake flows through this system, reshaping how value moves on Solana.
* **Not all MEV is harmful**. Bundles enable value-creating strategies like protected arbitrage and cross-protocol coordination.
* Developers must design**MEV-aware transactions.**Use bundles, simulate fees, and route sensitive flows through private relays.
Since day one, Solana has focused on delivering unmatched speed and throughput, making it a go-to choice for high-performance blockchain applications. This approach has fueled massive on-chain activity, drawing in developers, retail users, and institutions alike. Its emphasis on performance continues to shape a vibrant and growing ecosystem.

### Table of Contents
**Note:**The MEV landscape on Solana is rapidly changing. This page will be updated periodically with new developments. Read our latest[Solana MEV Report](https://www.helius.dev/blog/solana-mev-report)(Jan 2025).
## [Takeaways](#takeaways)
This post aims to provide a baseline understanding of how MEV on Solana works. In short:
* MEV on Solana is not dead.
* Not all MEV is bad.
* Profitable frontrunning is possible across DEX liquidity venues structures, not just AMMs.
* Solanaâ€™s continuous block production and lack of an in-protocol mempool changes the default behavior and social dynamics of the chain.
* Someone else may fork or try to otherwise replicate Jitoâ€™s out-of-protocol mempool to extract more MEV, but it is hard both technically and socially.
* Many validators support the decision to remove the Jito mempool, foregoing sandwiching revenue, in favor of the long-term growth and health of Solana.## [Introduction](#introduction)

Maximal Extractable Value (MEV) refers to any value derived from adding, removing, or reordering the transactions within a given block.

# Jito Labs
A Complete Guide for Innovators
![Jito Labs](https://blockchain.oodles.io/wp-content/themes/blockchain-child/assets/images/sc/jito-labs.png)
## What Jito Labs Is (and Is Not)
It builds MEV and block-building infrastructure for Solana. It operates core components that improve ordering, latency, and rewards. Its stack includes the Jito-Solana validator client, the Block Engine and bundles, ShredStream, relayers, and a liquid staking program. You use these tools to route order flow, protect users, and capture lawful MEV. You also use them to observe blocks faster and coordinate complex transactions.
The platform does not sell retail â€œtrading bots.â€ It ships infrastructure, clients, and APIs that others integrate. The audience includes validators, searchers, builders, dApps, wallets, and institutional treasuries. Each group plugs into different surfaces and policies. Each group also assumes different operational risks.
## Audience Paths
1
### Validators
Run the Jito-Solana client and connect a relayer. Configure MEV tip collection and payment programs. Monitor leader schedules and slot health. Review runbooks for co-hosted or separate relayer deployments. Track MEV rewards and validator performance across epochs.
2
### Searchers and HFT firms
Build bundles for auction. Use gRPC or JSON-RPC for fast sending. Test revert protection and atomic execution. Simulate routes and fees before bidding. Align with Block Engine policy and rate limits.
3
### dApps, wallets, and bot platforms
Use private routing to avoid harmful orderflow leakage. Use low-latency send to land time-sensitive transactions. Use bundles for multi-tx atomicity. Provide users with MEV protection paths as defaults.
4
### Stakers and Treasuries
Stake SOL to the Jito stake pool and receive JitoSOL. Earn staking rewards plus MEV-driven yield. Review program docs and risk notes before onboarding capital. Track TVL, APY, and integrations in the staking hub.

content.title: Bullet: Solana-Based Perp DEX on L2
content.summary: zerokn0wledge_ highlights Bullet, a Solana-based perp DEX implemented as a network extension. Bullet is a ZK-powered L2 appchain built with the Sovereign SDK, using Celestia for data availability and SuccinctLabs' SP1 zkVM for ZK proofs verified on Solana. It features a Rust-based matching engine and plans for an SVM-based execution environment.

bullets: Solana-based perp DEX implemented as a network extension.
ZK-powered L2 appchain built with Sovereign SDK.
Rust-based matching engine with 1ms latency.
Celestia for cheap and scalable data availability.
SuccinctLabs' SP1 zkVM for ZK proofs verified on Solana.
NOMT database structure.
SVM-based, HyperEVM-style execution environment (BulletSVM).
Integrated borrowing/lending and advanced trading features.
Seamless UX powered by wallet/gas abstraction.

images.title: Bullet: Solana-Based Perp DEX Architecture
images.description: The image is an infographic illustrating the architecture of Bullet, a Solana-based perpetual DEX. The diagram is structured in a layered format, starting with "Customizable to the Core" at the top. Below this, it details "Bullet Core," a VM-less architecture designed for unlimited compute and complex DeFi operations, utilizing ZKVM for proof generation. Beneath the core is "Bullet SVM," which enables permissionless smart contracts that extend BulletCore's DeFi primitives via pre-compile integration. The core components include "dApps" at the top, with modules for "Spot Trading" and "Borrow/Lend," and "Derivatives CLOB." The "bullet" logo is positioned centrally. The infrastructure layers include "ZK Rollup," "Solana + Celestia" for settlement and data availability, and "L1." The image also includes the text "CLOB Season by A1 Research."

images.title: Bullet: Solana-Based Perp DEX on L2 - Architecture Overview
images.description: This infographic provides an overview of the Bullet protocol, a Solana-based perpetual DEX operating on a Layer 2 (L2) solution. The image is divided into four key components: Execution, Settlement, Consensus, and Data Availability. Execution is described as a pure Rust environment without VM restrictions, built with a sovereign SDK. Settlement involves ZK proving of execution data posted to Celestia via Succinct SP1, with verification on Solana L1. Consensus relies on Solana L1 validators and consensus as the underlying trust assumption. Data Availability is achieved by posting all execution data from the Bullet rollup to Celestia, ensuring cheap and efficient data availability. The image also features logos for Bullet, Solana, and Celestia, indicating the technologies and platforms involved.

content.summary: A1 Research reports on HyperLiquid's success as a decentralized exchange, noting its $1B annual revenue, 700K users, and 30% market dominance. Hyperliquid has surpassed Robinhood in trading volume for three months straight.

bullets: Performance-first design: HyperCore L1 delivers low latency.
Token and timing alignment: $HYPE buyback mechanism creates buying pressure.
Community sovereignty: HIP-3 and HyperEVM expand the platform's capabilities.
HyperBFT: Consensus mechanism optimizes low-latency and high-throughput transaction processing.
HyperCore: RustVM-based execution layer designed for orderbook trading and financial primitives.
HyperEVM: Smart contract execution layer that runs on the same validator set and consensus as HyperCore.
Hyperliquid's advantage lies in its integrated performance, architecture, and liquidity.
Competitors like dYdX v4, GMX, EdgeX, and Lighter chase volume via airdrops, low fees, or modular architecture.
Hyperliquid's infrastructure moat remains substantial, as most competitors either inherit AMM-related inefficiencies or face the challenge of bootstrapping deep liquidity from scratch.

This revolution has closed the performance gap that once made high-frequency onchain trading impossible.
Protocols like Hyperliquid have proven that CEX-grade performance on a fully decentralized CLOB is achievable.
The competitive landscape is defined by two competing architectural philosophies.
The Modular Approach involves assembling bespoke L2 appchains from unbundled components.
The Monolithic Renaissance involves achieving breakthrough performance through vertical integration.

content.title: Perpetual DEX Comparison: Hyperliquid vs. Lighter vs. edgeX
content.description: This infographic provides a comparative analysis of three perpetual decentralized exchanges (DEXs): Hyperliquid, Lighter, and edgeX. The comparison covers performance data and platform features. Performance data includes volume 30D, percentage changes in 30D volume, active OI (Open Interest), volume-OI ratio, revenue 30D, number of users, number of pairs, new listings, token/points, and LP yield. Platform features include max leverage, taker/maker fees, infrastructure, settlement layer, market type, throughput, and major features. Hyperliquid shows a volume 30D of 336B, +25% changes, 15B active OI, a volume-OI ratio of 0.55, 58M revenue 30D, 658K users, 180 pairs, +11 new listings, token/points at ~53B and $53/token, and a 7.8% LP yield. Lighter has a volume 30D of 149B, +76% changes, 884M active OI, a volume-OI ratio of 3.5, no revenue 30D data, 85K users, 71 pairs, +27 new listings, token/points if 3-5B ~72-150/point, and a 57.5% LP yield. edgeX shows a volume 30D of 49B, +126% changes, 435M active OI, a volume-OI ratio of 2.3, 19M revenue 30D, 63K users, 84 pairs, +36 new listings, token/points if 3-5B ~90-150/point, and an 11.4% LP yield. Hyperliquid offers 40x max leverage, 0.01%, 0.045% taker/maker fees, L1 with HyperBFT infrastructure, Hyperliquid L1 settlement, CLOB market type, 200k/sec throughput, and major features including best depth for >15m BTC revenue buyback, strong ecosystem, and HIP3 catalyst. Lighter provides 50x max leverage, 0, 0 taker/maker fees, ZK-rollup infrastructure, ETH settlement, CLOB market type, 10k/sec throughput, and major features including 0 fee points program, a16z backed, and highest LP yield. edgeX offers 100x max leverage, 0.015%, 0.038% taker/maker fees, ZK-rollup infrastructure, ETH settlement, CLOB market type, 200k/sec throughput, and major features including best depth for <6M BTC, points program, mobile native, and MM backed.

content.title: Bullish case: Why $HYPE leads
content.summary: Thread-style bullish argument from GLC Research arguing Hyperliquid ($HYPE) remains market leader vs. competitors. Key points: copycat competitors, higher margins and no VC pressure, stronger resources and team, healthier volume/OI ratios, organic growth from builder codes and DATs, USDH and product stack diversify revenue, 99% buybacks align incentives, ability to compress fees or out-incentivize rivals post-TGE. Author links to a longer Hyperliquid research piece and discloses personal bias; thread focuses only on bullish points.

bullets: GLC argues Hyperliquid is the pace-setter; many competitors are copycats and lack innovation.
Claims Hyperliquid enjoys higher profit margins and no VC pressure, enabling long-term focus.
Author emphasizes Hyperliquidâ€™s larger resources, team growth (11â†’soon14), and organic builder-driven growth.
Says Hyperliquid has healthier Volume/OI ratios than competitors reliant on points campaigns pre-TGE.
Highlights USDH, HyperEVM, HIP-3, builder codes and DATs as revenue/distribution levers.
Notes 99% buybacks, staking-to-fee reductions, and a claimed clean P/E framework as token-supportive mechanics.
Acknowledges 0-fee competitors may be unsustainable but Hyperliquid can compress fees to apply pressure.
Warns competitors could still gain share after TGE; they also have capital to out-incentivize if desired.
Author discloses bias and that thread only covers bullish points; invites contrary views.

content.title: HyperLiquid Stack: BuilderCodes, CoreWriter, HIP-3
content.summary: Sumcap analyzes HyperLiquid's tech stack: HyperBFT, HyperCore, HyperEVM, Builder Codes, Read Precompiles, CoreWriter, HIP-3, and HLP. Hyperliquid is evolving into a financial infrastructure. Key point: Hyperliquid's tech stack.

bullets: Hyperliquid is best explained as a 3-part, performant tech stack for on-chain finance: HyperBFT, HyperCore, HyperEVM.
From these 3 core parts extend HyperLiquidâ€™s brand new upgrades: Read Precompiles, CoreWriter, Builder Codes, and Permissionless market creation (HIP-3).
These extensions reinforce the core philosophy that the space was in need of: transparency, removing middlemen, and openness.
Hyperliquid has quickly established itself as the dominant player in the perp DEX space, now holding a market share of 50% - 65%.
Since launch, Hyperliquid has grown the pie for on-chain perpetuals. Previously, the entire sector serviced $10-20B in weekly volume; Nowadays, >$100B weeks are not uncommon.
Hyperliquid has also built enough of a liquidity moat and cult following that it can now reasonably compete with CEX behemoths like Binance, servicing 12% of Binanceâ€™s volume in July 2025.
Hyperliquid's strategic evolution will be fundamentally driven by a shift from a single-product exchange to a foundational financial infrastructure.

This is made possible by the synergistic effect of its recent upgrades: 1) Builder Codes, 2) HIP-3, and 3) CoreWriter, which form a powerful, self-reinforcing flywheel that fundamentally expands its Total Addressable Market (TAM).
Hyperliquid is scaling into a multi-trillion dollar opportunity.

content.title: The Perp Architecture Endgame
content.summary: Perpetual futures dominate crypto market structure: October perp volume hit ~$9T vs ~$3T spot. DEXs capture ~20% market share and rising. Four perp DEX architectures evaluated: Hyperliquid (monolithic L1 CLOB; high throughput but centralized validator risk; OI ~$6.4B), Lighter (zk app-chain on Ethereum; provable priceâ€‘time, high volume ~300B, strong composability), Extended (hybrid offâ€‘chain matcher + Starknet settlement; good throughput but sequencer liveness risk), Jupiter (Solana poolâ€‘toâ€‘trader JLP; high TVL ~$1.7B, limited OI scale). Key axes: self-custody, matching, liquidations, oracles, governance. Conclusion: architectures that inherit Ethereum settlement and enable composability (zk app-chains / rollups) best positioned to scale market share long-term.

bullets: Perpetual futures are cash-settled, expiry-free derivatives anchored to spot via funding payments.
October perp volume reached ~$9 trillion; spot ~ $3 trillion in same period.
DEXs account for ~20% of perp volume (up from ~5% a year earlier).
Open interest is preferred over volume as a signal of sticky risk and market quality.
Exchange manages matching, margining, funding, liquidations and a loss absorption waterfall (insurance fund, ADL).
Five trust axes: self-custody/settlement, matching/execution, liquidations, oracles, governance/upgradability.
At-scale market makers require low latency and deep liquidity to enable a non-toxic taker flywheel.
Composability with broader DeFi (especially Ethereum) multiplies collateral and cross-margin utility.
Hyperliquid: custom L1 CLOB with HyperBFT, claims 200k TPS, median latency ~200ms; OI ~$6.4B, TVL ~$4.2B.
Lighter: zk app-chain on Ethereum with provable state transitions and price-time proofs; monthly volume ~300B, OI ~1.7B, TVL ~1.2B.
Extended: hybrid off-chain matcher + Starknet settlement; inherits validity proofs but depends on Starknet liveness and centralized multisig upgrades.
Jupiter: Solana pool-to-trader JLP; TVL ~$1.7B, high retail flow, capital-inefficient with OI capped by TVL.
Monolithic L1s (Hyperliquid) trade decentralization for latency; validator concentration produced governance interventions.
ZK app-chains anchor custody to Ethereum while enabling high throughput; remaining issues: MEV surface, oracle auth, timelocked upgradability.
Hybrid off-chain matching (Extended) risks opaque ordering unless moved to confidential compute or provable attestation.
Pool models (Jupiter) are composable on their native L1 but face hard ceilings on open interest and rely on keeper liveness.
Winning architecture likely inherits Ethereum security and composability while scaling like a CEX.
Lighter-style zk app-chains present the clearest path to trust minimization plus composability.
Hyperliquid leads today on OI but faces long-term security vs performance tradeoffs.
Jupiter and pool models remain product-market fit for retail and yield but limited for global price discovery.

content.title: Equity Perpetuals Landscape Report
content.summary: Perps can capture ~$48T/month 0DTE demand. Perpetual futures replicate linear, theta-free leveraged exposure and enable 24/7 capture of overnight and news-driven equity returns. US regulatory constraints (Shadâ€‘Johnson) block retail single-stock perps, shifting product-market fit to permissionless onchain venues. Viable onchain equityâ€‘perp designs require continuous oracles, deep twoâ€‘way liquidity, and reliable hedging across TradFi hours. Hyperliquid (HIPâ€‘3 + Unit/Trade.XYZ) dominates distribution; Ostium, Vest, and Solana tokenized spot models present alternative tradeoffs. Market sizing, liquidity data, and product architectures support a nearâ€‘term consolidation around HIPâ€‘3.

bullets: Perpetual futures replicate high-leverage 0DTE demand without theta decay.
~$48T/month 0DTE notional implies a ~40x expansion opportunity vs crypto perp volumes.
Shadâ€‘Johnson Accord effectively bars US retail single-stock perps without dual clearing.
Doddâ€‘Frank/CFTC and SEC rules require DCM/SEF execution and CCP clearing for equity SBS.
Continuous, robust oracles for intraday and overnight price formation.
Deep twoâ€‘way orderbooks to stabilize mark, funding, and prevent liquidation cascades.
Hedging rails that reconcile 24/7 onchain settlement with T+1/T+2 TradFi liquidity.
Hyperliquid (HIPâ€‘3) offers institutional-grade CLOB, distributor moat, and Deployers (Unit, Felix).
Ostium uses peerâ€‘toâ€‘pool oracle pricing with SOFR funding but halts weekends for offchain hedging.
Vest provides zkRisk riskâ€‘coherent margining; Solana enables xStock spot-backed hedges and atomic crossâ€‘margin.
Expect 12â€“18 months of consolidation around HIPâ€‘3 and Unit/Trade.XYZ distribution dominance.
Non-US APAC overnight flow (~80% of overnight volume) creates a large offshore addressable market.
Token/points exposure paths: HYPE (ecosystem capture), protocol points programs, or future tokens from deployers.

## The Rise of Perp DEXs: A New Era in Decentralized Trading

Perpetual decentralized exchanges (Perp DEXs) are revolutionizing the cryptocurrency trading landscape. In September 2025, trading volumes on Perp DEXs surpassed $1 trillion, accounting for over 20% of centralized exchange (CEX) perpetual futures volumeâ€”a dramatic increase from less than 2% in 2022. This surge underscores the growing demand for decentralized, transparent, and efficient trading platforms.

Among the top players in this space, **Hyperliquid** has emerged as a leader, leveraging cutting-edge technology and innovative features to redefine the trading experience. This article delves into how Hyperliquid is shaping the future of decentralized trading, its unique architecture, competitive advantages, and the challenges it faces.

## Hyperliquidâ€™s Architecture: Built for Speed and Scalability

Hyperliquid distinguishes itself with a proprietary Layer 1 blockchain built using the Arbitrum Orbit tech stack. This advanced architecture supports a fully on-chain order book and matching engine, delivering millisecond-level processing speeds. Unlike competitors that rely on existing blockchains, Hyperliquidâ€™s dedicated infrastructure eliminates performance bottlenecks, ensuring seamless trading even during high market activity.

### Key Features of Hyperliquidâ€™s Architecture

- **On-Chain Order Book**: Guarantees transparency and decentralization by recording all trades directly on the blockchain.

- **Millisecond Processing**: Offers a trading experience comparable to traditional CEXs, attracting both retail and institutional traders.

- **Scalability**: Handles high trading volumes without compromising performance, as evidenced by its $2.7 trillion cumulative trading volume and $20 billion daily trading volume.

# Perpetual DEXs intensify competition as Hyperliquid faces new rivals

[Aster](https://cryptorank.io/news/tag/aster) [USDT](https://cryptorank.io/news/tag/usdt) [Hype](https://cryptorank.io/news/tag/hype) [Sun](https://cryptorank.io/news/tag/sun) [EdgeX](https://cryptorank.io/news/tag/edgex) [SunPerp](https://cryptorank.io/news/tag/sunperp)

Sep, 22, 2025

3 min read

by Hristina Vasileva

for CryptoPolitan

**Perpetual DEXs are starting a new competition, aiming to challenge the leading position and first-mover advantage of Hyperliquid. Other chains are launching competitive platforms, boosting their liquidity and token price.**

The perpetual DEXs narrative is heating up, as competitors try to challenge the position of Hyperliquid. The successful model emerged with a relatively small team, becoming one of the top venues for trading, price predictions and high-profile whale moves. Hyperliquid is now battling to retain its top spot, after HYPE sank under $50. New arrivals are trying to gain attention and liquidity, as perpetual DEXs turned into a key piece of DeFi infrastructure.

HYPE sank from its recent highs, just as competitors were emerging on the perpetual futures DEXs market. \| Source: [CoinGecko](https://www.coingecko.com/en/coins/hyperliquid).

Based on fees and daily users, Hyperliquid had an undeniable first-mover advantage. The perpetual futures DEX was also fully permissionless, tapping US-based traders with the potential for high-risk, high-return trades.

Hyperliquid is still the leader in terms of daily fees, though the newly launched Aster and EdgeX are moving up the chart.

At one point, the perpetual futures DEXs were among the top 10 fee producers, with Hyperliquid second only to Tether.

rawResponse.title: Exploring Hyperliquid: Innovation in the Perp DEX Landscape
rawResponse.text:
Exploring Hyperliquid: Innovation in the Perp DEX Landscape

[Osgur Murphy O Kane](https://research.nansen.ai/analysts/osgur-murphy-o-kane)

Key Takeaways

10 min read

- Hyperliquid is a highly performant L1 perpetuals DEX capable of 20k TPS. It has grown to regularly rank in the top 3 perp DEXs by volume thanks to its smooth UX, easy onboarding via its Arbitrum bridge, and wide range of popular tokens listed (over 100 at the time of writing).
- Key features include hyperps which are essentially perp contracts for unlisted tokens e.g. ZRO (LayerZero). In addition, the community can deposit USDC into vaults where they can benefit from market making and liquidation strategies on the platform.
- A points program is running until April, where 1m points are distributed each week. Participating in the protocol's various features earns users points.
- The project remains in its infancy and is expected to decentralize its validator set later this year. It will be interesting to observe what effect, if any, this has on performance. In addition, a new consensus algorithm is being developed with the intention of bringing the protocol on par with CEXs. Whether or not the protocol can achieve these aims will be key in determining its future success.

## Introduction

Hyperliquid is an L1 perp DEX (with an Arbitrum bridge) that is capable of 20k orders per second with a fully on-chain order book. It seeks to directly compete with CEXs in terms of user experience and cost and has become a notable player in the DEX space. It offers a very wide range of assets for leverage trading (101 as of 5 Jan 2024), combined with a CEX-like UX that makes it very attractive to degens.

It opened up a points program in November 2023 stated to last for 6 months (until April 2024). This has notably increased usage across all metrics on the exchange, and volumes have ranged from $190m - to almost $1b each day since 4 December 2023. Many expect an airdrop to be tied to this points program.

searchParams.query: what are Hyperliquid's competitive advantages over other perp DEXs

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The search results are highly targeted to the query. Almost every result (with the exception of one regarding the 'Bullet' protocol) focuses specifically on Hyperliquid's market position, technical architecture, and competitive edge over rivals like dYdX, GMX, and Jupiter.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The data provided is exceptionally granular, including specific technical details (HyperBFT, HyperCore, HyperEVM), financial metrics (Revenue per employee, Volume/OI ratios), and comparative tables showing exact throughput and latency figures against other DEXs.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: The density is high, though there is some repetition across the 12 results regarding market share percentages and the 'purpose-built L1' narrative. One result about the 'Bullet' protocol is less relevant, but generally, the content is very efficient.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: The results provide a 360-degree view of advantages: technical (custom L1, 200k TPS), economic (no VC funding, HYPE buybacks), ecosystem (HIP-3, builder codes), and market (dominance in volume and OI). It even includes future-looking advantages like equity perpetuals.
key_strengths: Comprehensive technical breakdown of Hyperliquid's custom L1 stack (HyperBFT/HyperCore).
Detailed comparative data (tables and charts) contrasting Hyperliquid with specific competitors like Lighter and edgeX.
Strong focus on unique economic advantages, such as the absence of VC funding and high revenue-per-employee metrics.
Insight into the 'flywheel' effects of HIP-3 and Builder Codes for ecosystem growth.
key_weaknesses: One result (Post ID 172416) focuses on a different protocol ('Bullet'), which is only tangentially related as a competitor.
Slight redundancy in basic stats (market share, TPS) across multiple news/tweet summaries.
evaluation.overall_assessment: This is an excellent search result set that provides deep, multi-faceted insights into Hyperliquid's competitive advantages. It moves beyond superficial marketing claims to provide technical and quantitative evidence (latency, throughput, revenue metrics) that clearly differentiates the platform from other perp DEXs. The inclusion of architectural comparisons and tokenomic strategies makes it highly useful for professional-level analysis.

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The search results directly address the query with multiple articles focusing specifically on Hyperliquid's competitive advantages, technical architecture, and market position compared to other perp DEXs.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The results include high-quality insights from reputable sources like Nansen, QuickNode, and OKX. However, several results are cluttered with navigation menus, and some snippets are too brief to be useful.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: While the core information is excellent, there is a significant amount of boilerplate text, header/footer navigation, and redundant introductory content across several search results (e.g., results 5, 10, and 13).
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: The search contents provide a comprehensive list of advantages including the custom L1 architecture (HyperBFT/HyperCore), high performance (20k TPS), unique product offerings (Hyperps), tokenomics (HYPE buybacks), and user experience (CEX-like UI). It lacks a detailed fee-to-fee comparison chart with specific competitors, but covers the conceptual advantages well.
key_strengths: Identifies technical differentiators like the proprietary L1 blockchain and HyperBFT consensus.
Highlights unique product features such as 'Hyperps' (pre-launch perps) and permissionless market creation (HIP-3).
Provides specific market data including market share (70-80%) and volume metrics.
Details tokenomic advantages, specifically the 97% revenue buyback model and lack of VC allocations.
key_weaknesses: Several results consist mostly of website navigation and metadata rather than content.
Multiple results appear to be forward-dated to late 2025, which may indicate SEO-optimized or AI-generated filler content from some sources.
Redundancy between articles describing the 'perp DEX wars' without adding new unique data points in later results.
evaluation.overall_assessment: The search results are highly successful in answering the user's query. They provide a clear and multi-faceted view of why Hyperliquid is currently leading the perp DEX space, covering technical, product, and economic advantages. Despite some noise and redundant snippets, the top results from QuickNode, OKX, and Nansen offer deep, actionable insights that allow for a thorough understanding of the platform's edge over competitors like dYdX or GMX.

## The Rise of Perp DEXs: A New Era in Decentralized Trading

Perpetual decentralized exchanges (Perp DEXs) are revolutionizing the cryptocurrency trading landscape. In September 2025, trading volumes on Perp DEXs surpassed $1 trillion, accounting for over 20% of centralized exchange (CEX) perpetual futures volumeâ€”a dramatic increase from less than 2% in 2022. This surge underscores the growing demand for decentralized, transparent, and efficient trading platforms.

Among the top players in this space, **Hyperliquid** has emerged as a leader, leveraging cutting-edge technology and innovative features to redefine the trading experience. This article delves into how Hyperliquid is shaping the future of decentralized trading, its unique architecture, competitive advantages, and the challenges it faces.

## Hyperliquidâ€™s Architecture: Built for Speed and Scalability

Hyperliquid distinguishes itself with a proprietary Layer 1 blockchain built using the Arbitrum Orbit tech stack. This advanced architecture supports a fully on-chain order book and matching engine, delivering millisecond-level processing speeds. Unlike competitors that rely on existing blockchains, Hyperliquidâ€™s dedicated infrastructure eliminates performance bottlenecks, ensuring seamless trading even during high market activity.

### Key Features of Hyperliquidâ€™s Architecture

- **On-Chain Order Book**: Guarantees transparency and decentralization by recording all trades directly on the blockchain.

- **Millisecond Processing**: Offers a trading experience comparable to traditional CEXs, attracting both retail and institutional traders.

- **Scalability**: Handles high trading volumes without compromising performance, as evidenced by its $2.7 trillion cumulative trading volume and $20 billion daily trading volume.

# Perpetual DEXs intensify competition as Hyperliquid faces new rivals

[Aster](https://cryptorank.io/news/tag/aster) [USDT](https://cryptorank.io/news/tag/usdt) [Hype](https://cryptorank.io/news/tag/hype) [Sun](https://cryptorank.io/news/tag/sun) [EdgeX](https://cryptorank.io/news/tag/edgex) [SunPerp](https://cryptorank.io/news/tag/sunperp)

3 min read

by Hristina Vasileva

for CryptoPolitan

**Perpetual DEXs are starting a new competition, aiming to challenge the leading position and first-mover advantage of Hyperliquid. Other chains are launching competitive platforms, boosting their liquidity and token price.**

The perpetual DEXs narrative is heating up, as competitors try to challenge the position of Hyperliquid. The successful model emerged with a relatively small team, becoming one of the top venues for trading, price predictions and high-profile whale moves. Hyperliquid is now battling to retain its top spot, after HYPE sank under $50. New arrivals are trying to gain attention and liquidity, as perpetual DEXs turned into a key piece of DeFi infrastructure.

HYPE sank from its recent highs, just as competitors were emerging on the perpetual futures DEXs market. \| Source: [CoinGecko](https://www.coingecko.com/en/coins/hyperliquid).

Based on fees and daily users, Hyperliquid had an undeniable first-mover advantage. The perpetual futures DEX was also fully permissionless, tapping US-based traders with the potential for high-risk, high-return trades.

Hyperliquid is still the leader in terms of daily fees, though the newly launched Aster and EdgeX are moving up the chart.

At one point, the perpetual futures DEXs were among the top 10 fee producers, with Hyperliquid second only to Tether.

## **Key takeaways**
1. DEX market is maturing with DEXs capturing 20% of crypto trading volume and perpetual futures accounting for 65% of DEX activity.
2. With a 76.7% market share and over $1.5 trillion in total volume, Hyperliquid is the undisputed leader in onchain perpetual futures.
3. HyperBFT (consensus), HyperCore (execution), and HyperEVM (smart contracts) operate in a unified state â€”enabling performance, liquidity, and composability on a single chain.
4. 97% of protocol revenue goes into buying back $HYPE. With no VC allocations, the model prioritizes community ownership and long-term deflation.
5. HyperUnit allows native BTC, ETH, and SOL deposits without custodial wrappers or synthetic assets, enabling true collateral mobility and regulatory-aware design.

    "text": "Exploring Hyperliquid: Innovation in the Perp DEX Landscape

[Osgur Murphy O Kane](https://research.nansen.ai/analysts/osgur-murphy-o-kane)

Key Takeaways

10 min read

- Hyperliquid is a highly performant L1 perpetuals DEX capable of 20k TPS. It has grown to regularly rank in the top 3 perp DEXs by volume thanks to its smooth UX, easy onboarding via its Arbitrum bridge, and wide range of popular tokens listed (over 100 at the time of writing).
- Key features include hyperps which are essentially perp contracts for unlisted tokens e.g. ZRO (LayerZero). In addition, the community can deposit USDC into vaults where they can benefit from market making and liquidation strategies on the platform.
- A points program is running until April, where 1m points are distributed each week. Participating in the protocol's various features earns users points.
- The project remains in its infancy and is expected to decentralize its validator set later this year. It will be interesting to observe what effect, if any, this has on performance. In addition, a new consensus algorithm is being developed with the intention of bringing the protocol on par with CEXs. Whether or not the protocol can achieve these aims will be key in determining its future success.

## Introduction

Hyperliquid is an L1 perp DEX (with an Arbitrum bridge) that is capable of 20k orders per second with a fully on-chain order book. It seeks to directly compete with CEXs in terms of user experience and cost and has become a notable player in the DEX space. It offers a very wide range of assets for leverage trading (101 as of 5 Jan 2024), combined with a CEX-like UX that makes it very attractive to degens.

It opened up a points program in November 2023 stated to last for 6 months (until April 2024). This has notably increased usage across all metrics on the exchange, and volumes have ranged from $190m - to almost $1b each day since 4 December 2023. Many expect an airdrop to be tied to this points program.

question.query: what is Ethena's architecture and how does it maintain stability

content.title: Ethena's Crypto Dollar War Strategy
content.summary: Analysis of Ethena's USDe growth, reaching $3B in 4 months. Key factors include high yields, secure collateral via UStb, and strategic partnerships. The stablecoin market evolves with diverse use cases like trading, DeFi, and payments. Ethena aims to be the settlement token for trading with highest yields.

bullets: USDe reached $3B market cap in 4 months, making it the fastest-growing crypto dollar.
Employs UStb backed by BlackRock's BUIDL fund, liquid stables, and a reserve fund.
sUSDe generates yield through staking rewards, delta-neutral market strategies, and stablecoin yields.
Unique 'unforkable' architecture for minting USDe and generating yield.
USDe is positioned as a settlement token for trading with high yields.
Expansion strategies include product diversification (UStb), multichain expansion, building the Ethena Network, and partnerships with centralized exchanges.

images.title: Ethena's Crypto Dollar War Strategy
images.description: The image is a promotional graphic for an article titled "The Verge of Crypto Dollar War and Strategy of Ethena (Feat. UStb, Network)". The article, published on October 21, 2024, is estimated to be a 28-minute read and discusses Ethena's USDe, which has seen rapid growth, reaching a $3 billion market cap in just four months, making it the fastest-growing crypto dollar to date. The article covers key takeaways and a case study on Ethena, focusing on its rapid growth and high yields.

content.title: Ethena Backing Asset Custody Overview
content.description: The image is a screenshot from the Ethena documentation, focusing on "Backing Asset Custody." It explains how Ethena's "Treasury Management" system interacts with "Off-Exchange Settlement" providers to manage backing assets for USDe. The overview describes the peg stability mechanism of USDe, where the system increases or decreases delta hedging derivatives positions as users mint and redeem USDe. The image highlights that users transfer and request backing assets in exchange for/from USDe. Ethena needs to safely and securely custody protocol backing assets, transfer assets between smart contracts and users, and delegate/undelegate assets between "Off-Exchange Settlement" providers and centralized exchanges. The image also provides examples of internal workflows, such as when a user successfully mints USDe, the asset is transferred to the Minting smart contract, and then directly to the "Off-Exchange Settlement" provider. Another example shows the internal hedging system opening a short derivatives position to hedge increased delta exposure.

content.title: Ethena Protocol Overview
content.description: The image is a diagram illustrating the Ethena Protocol. It describes Ethena as a synthetic dollar protocol on Ethereum. The USDe synthetic dollar maintains its peg through delta-hedging Ethereum and Bitcoin collateral. The protocol combines yields from staked assets with funding and basis spreads from perpetual and futures markets. The diagram likely shows the flow of assets, the hedging mechanisms, and the sources of yield generation within the Ethena Protocol.

content.title: How Ethena Works Diagram
content.description: This infographic illustrates the operational flow of Ethena, a synthetic dollar protocol. The process begins with users depositing USD collateral, which then flows into the creation of sUSDe, allowing staking for protocol rewards. Simultaneously, Ethena issues USDe (synthetic dollar), which is maintained by balancing spot and short positions. Collateral is deployed in spot BTC/ETH and delta-neutral short perps. Yield flows from funding payments and staking rewards. The diagram uses a circular flow to show the interconnected steps of the Ethena protocol.

content.title: Ethena custody shift to Kraken, Anchorage, Zodia
content.summary: A governance proposal would add Kraken, Anchorage Digital, and Zodia as Ethena custody partners to hold stablecoins (USDC, USDT, PYUSD, USDtb) and Aave yield-bearing tokens. The tweet explains why these custodians matter, contrasts them with existing offâ€‘exchange settlement custodians (Copper, Ceffu), summarizes a 50+ criteria Risk Committee framework, and links the change to Ethena's shift from perp-backed to stablecoin/DeFi treasury backing.

bullets: Proposal advancing to add Kraken, Anchorage Digital, and Zodia as custodians for stablecoins and Aave yield tokens.
New custodians will NOT perform off-exchange settlement for perp positions; they hold stablecoin and DeFi treasury assets.
Existing custodians (Copper, Ceffu) previously enabled off-exchange settlement and operational separation from exchanges.
Risk Committee created a 50+ criteria evaluation with weighted scoring and minimum floors per category.
Weights: Security & custody 40% (8/10 floor); Operational capability 30% (7/10 floor); Protocol requirements 30% (8/10 floor).
Hard exclusions: prior client fund loss, SLA <99.9% uptime, unverifiable attestations, no bankruptcy-remote structure.
October attestation: $5.2B in stablecoins across wallets and custody solutions.
Backing composition shifted: early year ~80% perps â†’ mid year 28% perps â†’ now ~65% stablecoins and yield assets.
Bybit Feb 2025 compromise showed off-exchange settlement prevented user losses; custody model proved operationally resilient.

content.title: Strata: yield tranching for Ethena USDe
content.summary: OAK Research summarizes Strataâ€™s tranche model for Ethenaâ€™s sUSDe: it splits sUSDe yield into srUSDe (senior) and jrUSDe (junior). srUSDe targets a floor yield anchored to Aave USDC/USDT rates for low-volatility, institution-friendly exposure; jrUSDe absorbs variability and captures excess yield, acting like leveraged exposure with higher volatility. Strata makes yield granular and composable, requires USDe/sUSDe to mint tranches, and could drive Ethena growth if widely adopted. OAK links a longer Early Bird article for a full breakdown.

bullets: Strata splits sUSDe yield into two ERCâ€‘20 tokens: srUSDe (senior) and jrUSDe (junior).
srUSDe receives a stable floor yield anchored to Aave USDC/USDT lending rates for predictable returns.
jrUSDe captures excess performance above the floor and bears the volatility, acting like leveraged yield exposure.
This mirrors TradFi tranche models (CDO/CLO) to introduce risk granularity missing from sUSDe.
Tranching enables tailored exposure for treasuries, funds, protocols, and retail users.
Minting srUSDe or jrUSDe requires USDe/sUSDe, so Strata growth would increase USDe demand and benefit Ethena.
Strata creates composable instruments that unlock new DeFi strategies and integrations.

content.title: OAK Early Bird: Strata yield tranching on USDe
content.summary: OAK Research's Early Bird deep-dive explains Strata, a Seasonâ€‘1 protocol that tranches Ethena's sUSDe yield into srUSDe (low-risk, floor-aligned yield) and jrUSDe (high-risk, leveraged yield). Describes Strata's Dynamic Yield Split (8â€‘hour cycle), minting constraints (only USDe/sUSDe), average 30â€‘day APYs (srUSDe ~4.17%, jrUSDe ~15.04%), Pendle/Euler/Morpho integrations for farming points, Season 0â†’1 timeline, and current airdrop/points mechanics and farming strategies.

bullets: Strata segments sUSDe's yield into two ERCâ€‘20 tranches: srUSDe (senior, capitalâ€‘preserving) and jrUSDe (junior, absorbs volatility).
srUSDe targets a floor yield tied to Aave USDC/USDT rates; jrUSDe captures excess yield with higher volatility.
Unlike Pendle, Strata only splits the yield stream (not principal vs yield tokens).
Both tranches are minted only with USDe or sUSDe and increase demand for Ethena products.
Dynamic Yield Split (DYS) runs on an 8â€‘hour cycle, allocating stable portions to senior tranche.
If sUSDe yield < floor, junior tranche absorbs contraction; if > floor, junior captures excess.
30â€‘day reference APYs reported: srUSDe ~4.17% (stable), jrUSDe ~15.04% (volatile).
Strata Season 0 (liquidity bootstrapping) ended Oct 13, 2025; Season 1 is live with mainnet activity.
Points earned by holding/minting srUSDe or jrUSDe; extra points from deploying assets on Euler, Morpho, Pendle.
Pendle markets (PT, YT, LP) are highlighted as efficient farming routes; YTâ€‘srUSDe currently most pointsâ€‘efficient.
YTs amplify points but expire at maturity (zero value afterwards); LP preserves capital while earning incentives.
No official Season 1 end date or TGE disclosed; Season 0 lasted ~3 months, implying similar cadence possible.
Tranching makes USDe yield composable for conservative treasuries and yieldâ€‘seeking strategies alike.
Adoption by institutions could expand USDe demand and Ethena ecosystem growth.
Strata's onâ€‘chain model preserves transparency and composability for new yield strategies.

images.title: USDe Distribution per Blockchain
images.description: This pie chart illustrates the distribution of USDe across different blockchains. Ethereum dominates with 96.5% of the USDe distribution. Other blockchains include Mantle (1.52%), Berachain (1.2%), BNB (0.39%), and Solana (0.26%). The chart is dated 21/04/2025 and sourced from DeFi Llama and OAK Research.

images.title: USDe Backing Breakdown
images.description: This infographic provides a breakdown of the backing assets behind USDe. The total backing plus reserve fund is $4.98B. The left side of the graphic details the backing composition, with 101.33% backing. The breakdown includes: 71.3% in Liquid stablecoins, 18.2% in ETH, 6.1% in BTC, 3.7% in ETH LSTs, and 0.7% in SOL. The right side of the graphic details the liquid stablecoins breakdown, with a total of $3.25B. The breakdown includes: 41% in USDtb, 35.2% in USDC, 16.6% in USDT, and 7.2% in sUSDS. The date of the information is 21/04/2025, and the source is Ethena Transparency, OAK Research.

rawResponse.title: What Is Ethena (ENA)? The Stable Yield Protocol Token ...
rawResponse.text:
## Key Takeaways

â€¢ Ethena's USDe is a synthetic dollar designed for stability without fiat backing.

â€¢ ENA serves as the governance token, allowing holders to influence protocol parameters and incentives.

â€¢ Yield for USDe comes from ETH staking rewards and funding payments from perpetual futures.

â€¢ Users should be aware of risks including market volatility, liquidity issues, and smart contract vulnerabilities.

â€¢ Ethena's ecosystem is expanding rapidly, integrating with various DeFi platforms and products.

Ethena is a decentralized protocol built around a â€œsynthetic dollarâ€ called USDe, designed to deliver a stable, on-chain asset with yield sourced from crypto-native markets. Its governance token, ENA, coordinates protocol parameters, incentives, and community decision-making. Ethenaâ€™s approach sits at the intersection of stablecoins, derivatives markets, and Ethereum staking, making it one of the most discussed crypto projects since its launch.

This article explains how USDe works, where its yield comes from, what ENA is for, major risks and considerations, and how users can interact with the ecosystem in 2025.

## The Big Idea: A Delta-Neutral Synthetic Dollar

Traditional stablecoins are backed by fiat reserves. Ethenaâ€™s USDe is different: it achieves dollar stability via a delta-neutral strategy. In short, USDe is collateralized by crypto assets (primarily staked ETH), while the protocol takes offsetting short positions in perpetual futures to hedge price risk. The goal is to maintain a stable dollar exposure while accruing yield from two sources:

- Staking rewards from ETH (via liquid staking derivatives such as stETH)
- Funding payments from perpetual futures (the â€œbasisâ€ trade)

For a deeper look at USDeâ€™s mechanism and risk framework, see Ethenaâ€™s documentation and transparency resources via the official docs and blog:

- Ethena Docs: [docs.ethena.fi](https://docs.ethena.fi/)
- Protocol Mechanics Overview: [USDe and sUSDe in the docs](https://docs.eth
